newsitem.title: POLAND: POLAND MAY QUARANTEE GDANSK SHIPYARD CREDIT.
newsitem.headline: POLAND MAY QUARANTEE GDANSK SHIPYARD CREDIT.

text.p: The Polish government may guarantee credit for the construction of ships at Nowa Stocznia Gdanska Sp. zoo if other parties would share the financial risk of the operation, the finance ministry said.

It said in a statement on Wednesday that an application by Bank Gdanski SA for government credit was turned down because it was incomplete and because a banking consortium which would finance the shops construction had yet not been formed.

Last month Nowa Stocznia Gdanska, carved out of the bankrupt Gdansk shipyard's assets, signed a contract with Germany's Schoeller Holding Ltd for the construction of five ships worth $27.5 million each.
The deal specified that Scholler would not give any pre-payments to the yard and that the construction would be financed by credit given by a consortium led by Bank Gdanski.
The old Gdansk shipyard -- where in 1980 Lech Walesa founded the first free trade union in the then Soviet bloc -- has operated under bankruptcy rules since August 1996.
Nowa Stocznia Gdanska is not burdened with its parent's debts which exceed 415 million zlotys ($142 million).
